importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2026 to 2029 is critical due to the projected funding shortfall and the need for intensified efforts in high-risk areas.

keyTakeAways: A $1.7 billion funding gap is expected through 2029, threatening global polio eradication efforts.
The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), including WHO and the Gates Foundation, will face a 30% budget reduction in 2026.
Reduced foreign aid, especially from the United States, and other major donors like Germany and the UK, are driving the funding shortfall.
The GPEI will focus on high-risk areas such as Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio remains endemic.
The initiative will adopt fractional dosing to stretch vaccine supplies and enhance coverage in vulnerable populations.
Vaccine-derived polio has been reported in 149 cases across countries, including Nigeria, highlighting risks in vaccine distribution.
Despite persistent cases, polio cases have declined since 2024, showing progress in global health interventions.
Eradication remains feasible with sustained commitment, but funding and political support are critical to success.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), led by the World Health Organization and including the Gates Foundation, faces a critical $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029, driven primarily by reduced foreign aid from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This financial strain threatens ongoing polio eradication efforts, especially in high-risk regions like Afghanistan and Pakistan, which continue to report wild polio cases. To address the shortfall, the GPEI will prioritize surveillance and vaccination in vulnerable areas, adopt cost-effective strategies such as fractional dosing, and collaborate with other health programs like measles initiatives. While polio cases have declined since 2024, persistent transmission and vaccine-derived outbreaks in places like Nigeria highlight the ongoing challenges. Experts stress that sustained global commitment and funding are essential to achieving polio eradication.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
